title: T-test
text: When you perform a hypothesis test of a single population mean μ using a Student's $$t-distribution$$ (often called a $$t-test)$$, there are fundamental assumptions that need to be met in order for the test to work properly. Your data should be a simple random sample that comes from a population that is approximately normally distributed. You use the sample standard deviation to approximate the population standard deviation.
speech: When you perform a hypothesis test of a single population mean μ using a Student's  t minus distribution  (often called a  t, minus test  , there are fundamental assumptions that need to be met in order for the test to work properly. Your data should be a simple random sample that comes from a population that is approximately normally distributed. You use the sample standard deviation to approximate the population standard deviation.

, there are fundamental assumptions that need to be met in order for the test to work properly. Your data should be a simple random sample that comes from a population that is approximately normally distributed. You use the sample standard deviation to approximate the population standard deviation.

title: Z-test
text: Recall what decisions must be made to decide what distribution would be best to perform hypothesis tests. When you use a normal distribution for a hypothesis test (often called a $$z-test)$$, a simple random sample is taken from the population and the population that you are working with is normally distributed or the sample size is sufficiently large.
speech: Recall what decisions must be made to decide what distribution would be best to perform hypothesis tests. When you use a normal distribution for a hypothesis test (often called a  z minus test  , a simple random sample is taken from the population and the population that you are working with is normally distributed or the sample size is sufficiently large.

, a simple random sample is taken from the population and the population that you are working with is normally distributed or the sample size is sufficiently large.

title: Hypothesis Distribution
text: Remember that degrees of freedom for $$t-test$$ distributions is $$n-1$$, where $$n$$ is the population. $$n$$ is $$6$$ in this case.
speech: Remember that degrees of freedom for  t minus test  distributions is  n, minus, 1 , where  n  is the population.  n  is  6  in this case.
